content:
üéì What It Is

üí° Core Degree:
A Master of Divinity (M.Div.) is a professional seminary degree traditionally aimed at preparing students for pastoral leadership, teaching, church planting, pastoral care, and related vocational ministries. It combines biblical studies, theology, pastoral skills, leadership, preaching, and ministry practice.

üí° Digital Ministry Focus:
Some schools now offer a digital ministry concentration or specialization within their M.Div. programs that specifically focuses on:

Using online platforms for evangelism and discipleship

Digital outreach strategy and building online faith communities

Creating, managing, and leading digital church services

Utilizing social media, websites, blogs, podcasts, and multimedia tools

Communicating faith effectively in today‚Äôs digital culture

This means you get traditional theological training plus practical skills for ministry in digital spaces‚Äîan increasingly important aspect of Christian work in the 21st century.

üìò What You Typically Study
An M.Div. with a digital ministry emphasis still includes the foundational seminary coursework, such as:

Biblical languages, Old & New Testament studies

Theology & Christian doctrine

Homiletics (preaching) and pastoral counseling

Church leadership & discipleship

Ethics and pastoral care

In addition, digital-focused courses may include:

Digital outreach & online evangelism strategies

Social media communication for ministry

Digital community building & engagement

Multimedia tools for worship and teaching

üß† Who It‚Äôs For
This degree is ideal if you‚Äôre called to:

Lead or expand a church‚Äôs digital ministry

Serve as a digital pastor / online campus pastor

Design, manage, or direct online church platforms

Create digital discipleship resources

Pastor or minister to global or remote faith communities

üíº Career & Ministry Paths
Graduates of an M.Div. with a digital ministry emphasis may work as:

Digital Ministry Leader / Director

Digital Pastor or Online Campus Pastor

Communications Liaison

Content Creator for Church Platforms

Online Discipleship Coordinator

Ministry Consultant for Digital Strategy

Many of these roles exist within churches, parachurch organizations, Christian nonprofits, or even faith-based startups and media ministries.

üìç Program Formats
Most digital ministry M.Div. programs are offered online, making them flexible for part-time students, working professionals, or bi-vocational ministers. Example programs include:

Liberty University ‚Äì M.Div. in Church Ministry in the Digital Age (fully online, ATS accredited)

Regent University ‚Äì M.Div. in Theology & Ministry with Online Ministry concentration (online with optional campus opportunities)

Other seminaries offer traditional M.Div. programs that may be combined with digital-themed elective courses.

üïê Time & Accreditation
A full M.Div. typically requires around 70‚Äì90+ credit hours and can take 3‚Äì4 years of full-time study, though many online programs allow part-time pacing.

Look for accreditation by bodies like the Association of Theological Schools (ATS)‚Äîimportant if you plan to serve in denominational or institutional ministry


MDiv in Digital Ministry
vs

MDiv in Biblical Informatics
1Ô∏è‚É£ Core Difference (In One Sentence)
MDiv in Digital Ministry ‚Üí Uses digital tools to do ministry

MDiv in Biblical Informatics ‚Üí Studies the Bible and theology through computational, data-driven, and AI-assisted systems

Think application vs. architecture.

2Ô∏è‚É£ MDiv in Digital Ministry (Practice-Focused)
üîπ What it REALLY is
A traditional MDiv with an added emphasis on:

Online church

Social media ministry

Streaming services

Digital evangelism

Content creation

üìå The theology stays mostly unchanged‚Äîonly the delivery method is modernized.

üîπ Typical mindset
‚ÄúHow do we preach, disciple, and pastor people online?‚Äù

üîπ Sample courses
Digital Evangelism

Online Church Leadership

Social Media for Ministry

Media & Worship Technology

Digital Discipleship

üîπ Graduate roles
Digital Pastor

Online Campus Pastor

Church Media Director

Communications Pastor

üîπ Strengths
‚úÖ Immediate church use
‚úÖ Easy adoption by existing churches
‚ùå Often tool-dependent (platforms change)
‚ùå Rarely produces new systems or technologies

3Ô∏è‚É£ MDiv in Biblical Informatics (System-Focused, Deeper)
üîπ What it REALLY is
A new academic‚Äìministry hybrid field that treats the Bible as:

A structured corpus

A knowledge system

A computational object

It asks:

‚ÄúHow can Scripture, theology, and doctrine be modeled, preserved, queried, and taught using intelligent systems?‚Äù

This is not about posting sermons‚Äîit‚Äôs about building the engines behind biblical tools.

üîπ Typical mindset
‚ÄúHow do we encode, structure, and safeguard biblical knowledge in digital systems without compromising doctrine?‚Äù

üîπ Core domains combined
Biblical Studies (KJV-centered, in your case)

Theology & Hermeneutics

Information Science

Knowledge Representation

AI-assisted biblical tools (as assistive, not authoritative)

Digital preservation & doctrinal integrity

üîπ Sample courses (aligned with your ideas)
Biblical Data Modeling

Scripture as Structured Knowledge

AI as a Tool in Biblical Research (KJV-anchored)

Digital Hermeneutics

Rule-Based Biblical Systems

Ethics of AI in Theology

Offline-first & Preservation-Focused Bible Systems

üîπ Graduate roles
Biblical Systems Architect

Bible Software Designer

Curriculum Engineer for Bible Colleges

AI-Assisted Research Ministry Director

Digital Archivist of Scripture

Founder of Bible-based SaaS / Web Apps (like your projects)

4Ô∏è‚É£ Side-by-Side Comparison
Aspect    Digital Ministry          Biblical Informatics
Focus Ministry delivery     Knowledge systems
Theology depth Standard seminary     Advanced + structured
Tech use Tools & platforms     Architecture & logic
AI role Optional content aid      Controlled, rule-based
Output Content & services     Systems & frameworks
Longevity Platform-dependent     Future-proof
Innovation Low‚Äìmedium     High
Academic uniqueness Common     Rare / pioneering
5Ô∏è‚É£ Why Biblical Informatics Fits YOU Better
Based on your stored goals and projects:

‚úî You build offline-first Bible apps
‚úî You want AI as a tool, not authority
‚úî You emphasize KJV centrality
‚úî You design rule-based systems
‚úî You want self-paced, mastery-based education
‚úî You aim to teach Bible + technology

üìå Digital Ministry trains users of technology
üìå Biblical Informatics trains creators and guardians of biblical systems

6Ô∏è‚É£ A Simple Analogy
Digital Ministry ‚Üí A preacher using a microphone

Biblical Informatics ‚Üí The engineer who designed the microphone, ensured clarity, and prevented distortion

7Ô∏è‚É£ Can They Coexist?
Yes‚Äîbut not as equals.

Digital Ministry can be a track or concentration
Biblical Informatics should be the degree core

This is exactly how your MDiv in Biblical Informatics stands out academically and spiritually.

8Ô∏è‚É£ Bottom Line
Choose Digital Ministry if you want to operate church tech

Choose Biblical Informatics if you want to build, preserve, and safeguard biblical knowledge systems


Why Biblical Informatics Matters
(And Why It Is Not Optional Anymore)
Executive Summary


The Core Problem Biblical Informatics Solves
The Church Has Entered a Technological Crisis Without a Theology of Technology
Today:

AI summarizes Scripture without doctrinal accountability

Bible apps rewrite meaning through paraphrase and algorithmic bias

Platforms decide visibility, interpretation, and reach

Data loss, format decay, and vendor lock-in threaten long-term preservation

Most pastors use tools they do not understand and cannot audit

The result is silent doctrinal erosion, not persecution.

Biblical Informatics exists to stop that.

What Biblical Informatics Actually Is
Not coding for coding‚Äôs sake.
Not ‚ÄúAI preaching.‚Äù
Not replacing pastors.

Biblical Informatics is:

The application of information science, logic, and system design to ensure that Scripture remains authoritative, stable, queryable, preservable, and correctly handled across generations and technologies.

It treats the Bible as:

A canon, not a dataset

A knowledge system, not content

A sacred text, not raw input

Why Theology Alone Is No Longer Sufficient
The Reformers fought corruption in interpretation.
This generation faces corruption in infrastructure.

If the system is wrong, the sermon will be wrong‚Äîeven if the preacher is sincere.

Consider:

Search ranking alters theology

AI autocomplete teaches doctrine

UX design shapes belief formation

Database structure determines what questions can be asked

Offline access determines who receives Scripture in restricted regions

These are theological issues, not technical ones.

Biblical Informatics addresses them directly.

What Makes Biblical Informatics Different from Digital Ministry
Digital Ministry Biblical Informatics
Uses platforms Designs systems
Consumes tools Builds frameworks
Focuses on delivery Focuses on integrity
Adapts to change Controls change
Platform-dependent Platform-agnostic
Short lifecycle Long-term preservation
Digital Ministry is tactical.
Biblical Informatics is strategic.

The KJV Example (Why This Matters Practically)
Without Biblical Informatics:

AI paraphrases the KJV

Meaning is normalized to modern theology

Verse boundaries are ignored

Cross-references are flattened

Authority subtly shifts from text to model

With Biblical Informatics:

KJV remains the immutable core

AI is rule-bound and assistive

No generative rewriting

Provenance is tracked

Interpretive boundaries are enforced

This is not preference‚Äîit is doctrinal stewardship.

The Real Output of Biblical Informatics
Graduates do not merely preach better‚Äîthey shape the future of biblical engagement.

They produce:

Offline-first Bible systems

Rule-based biblical assistants

Structured curricula with doctrinal safeguards

AI-resistant preservation models

Verifiable translation workflows

Canon-aware knowledge graphs

Self-paced mastery-based Bible education systems

These outlive platforms, trends, and even institutions.

Why the Church Will Need This Field (Sooner Than It Thinks)
Within 5‚Äì10 years:

AI-generated sermons will be common

Deepfake theology will emerge

‚ÄúBiblical summaries‚Äù will replace reading

Churches will outsource discernment to tools

Historical doctrines will be statistically ‚Äúoutvoted‚Äù

The question is not if harm occurs‚Äîbut who is trained to stop it.

Biblical Informatics trains those people.

Why This Is a Legitimate MDiv Track
The Master of Divinity historically prepares:

Pastors

Teachers

Guardians of doctrine

Biblical Informatics simply recognizes that:

The guardian role has moved from pulpits alone to systems, software, and logic layers.

This is not a departure from ministry.
It is ministry at the infrastructure level.

The Bottom Line
Digital Ministry helps the Church use technology.
Biblical Informatics helps the Church survive technology.

It is not trendy.
It is not flashy.
It is necessary.

If you care about:

Doctrinal integrity

Long-term Scripture preservation

AI without theological compromise

Teaching future generations responsibly

Then Biblical Informatics is not just worth adopting‚Äîit is a moral obligation for this era.


1. The Integrated Vision (Plainly Stated)
Digital Ministry answers the ‚Äúwhy and where.‚Äù
Biblical Informatics answers the ‚Äúhow and with what safeguards.‚Äù

Together, they form a single mandate:

To proclaim, teach, and preserve the Word of God faithfully through digital means without surrendering doctrinal authority to technology.

This is not a hybrid by convenience.
It is a necessary synthesis.

2. How They Complement (Not Compete)
Digital Ministry Contributes:
Missional reach (online, global, underserved)

Pastoral presence in digital spaces

Communication, discipleship, and worship delivery

Human-centered ministry concerns

Ecclesiology applied to online contexts

Biblical Informatics Contributes:
Scriptural integrity at the system level

Canon-aware data structures

Rule-based AI and search logic

Preservation, auditability, and provenance

Doctrinal boundaries in digital tools

üìå Digital Ministry without Informatics risks drift.
üìå Informatics without Digital Ministry risks detachment.

Together, they produce faithful digital shepherds who also understand the machinery behind the mission.

3. The Unified Minister Profile
A graduate of this merged MDiv is:

A pastor who understands platforms

A technologist who understands theology

A digital missionary who can audit his tools

A teacher who can build and safeguard curricula

A steward of Scripture in both message and medium

This is not a media specialist.
This is a digital-era divinity leader.

4. Structural Model (Conceptual, Not Curriculum Yet)
Core MDiv Foundation (Unchanged)
Old & New Testament

Theology & Doctrine

Hermeneutics

Homiletics

Pastoral Care

Church History

Ethics

Digital Ministry Layer (Application)
Digital Evangelism & Discipleship

Online Church Ecclesiology

Media & Worship Technologies

Pastoral Care in Digital Contexts

Digital Communication Ethics

Biblical Informatics Layer (Infrastructure)
Scripture as Structured Knowledge

Canon-Aware Information Systems

Rule-Based Biblical AI (Assistive Only)

Digital Hermeneutics

Preservation & Offline Bible Systems

Doctrinal Safeguards in Technology

üìå Ministry flows through systems‚Äîbut systems never replace ministry.

5. What This Degree Is NOT
Not ‚ÄúAI Pastoring‚Äù

Not tech-first ministry

Not platform training

Not trendy rebranding

It is theologically anchored, technologically literate, pastorally accountable ministry formation.

6. MDiv Degree Name Options (Ranked & Explained)
Below are academically defensible names that clearly signal both dimensions without sounding experimental or unserious.

ü•á Master of Divinity in Digital Ministry and Biblical Informatics
Best for clarity and transparency

Explicit

Honest

Immediately understandable

Ideal for new or independent institutions

üìå Long‚Äîbut unmistakable.

ü•à Master of Divinity in Digital Theology and Ministry Systems
Best for academic credibility

‚ÄúDigital Theology‚Äù anchors informatics theologically

‚ÄúMinistry Systems‚Äù avoids raw tech language

Appeals to accrediting bodies

ü•â Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry
Best if Informatics is the core

Signals innovation leadership

Positions Digital Ministry as applied outcome

Strong for curriculum builders and system designers

‚≠ê Master of Divinity in Technology-Integrated Ministry
Most conservative naming

Safest for traditional boards

Broad enough for growth

Informatics can be framed internally

üìå Less distinctive, but politically viable.

‚≠ê Master of Divinity in Digital Scripture and Ministry
Scripture-forward emphasis

Keeps Bible central

Subtly includes informatics

Attractive to conservative institutions

7. Recommended Final Choice (Based on Your Vision)
Given your emphasis on:

KJV centrality

Rule-based systems

Offline-first Bible tools

Curriculum engineering

AI as servant, not authority

‚úÖ Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry
This ordering is intentional:

Scripture before systems

Integrity before reach

Architecture before application

8. Final Word
This merged degree does something no standard MDiv does:

It prepares ministers not only to preach the Word, but to protect the Word in the age of machines.

That is not optional leadership.
That is pastoral responsibility in this generation.



Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry
Program Description

The Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry is a professional graduate degree designed to prepare ministers for faithful, wise, and effective service in an increasingly digital world. Rooted in historic Christian theology and pastoral formation, the program integrates rigorous biblical studies with responsible engagement in digital technologies used for teaching, discipleship, evangelism, and Scripture preservation.

This degree affirms that technology‚Äîlike other tools throughout church history‚Äîis neither inherently harmful nor authoritative. When properly understood and governed by biblical wisdom, it can serve the Church as a faithful instrument for proclaiming and stewarding the Word of God.

Program Purpose
The program equips students to:

Handle Scripture with theological integrity in both traditional and digital contexts

Understand how biblical texts are structured, preserved, and accessed within digital systems

Use modern tools, including digital platforms and assistive technologies, as servants of ministry rather than substitutes for pastoral authority

Lead congregations and ministries thoughtfully in online, hybrid, and technology-mediated environments

By combining Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry, the program forms ministers who are both theologically grounded and technologically literate, capable of discerning proper use while maintaining fidelity to Scripture.

Areas of Emphasis
Biblical Informatics focuses on the responsible handling of Scripture within digital environments. Students study how biblical texts are organized, transmitted, preserved, and supported by modern information systems, ensuring clarity, accuracy, and doctrinal faithfulness.

Digital Ministry emphasizes the practical application of digital tools for evangelism, discipleship, worship, teaching, and pastoral care. Students learn to minister effectively in digital spaces while maintaining biblical, ethical, and pastoral accountability.

Together, these emphases support the Church‚Äôs mission by ensuring that both the message and the means of ministry are handled wisely.

Ministerial Formation
Graduates of this program are prepared to serve as pastors, teachers, ministry leaders, and digital ministry coordinators who:

Proclaim and teach Scripture faithfully

Discern and supervise the use of digital tools in ministry settings

Provide pastoral care in both physical and digital contexts

Support the development and evaluation of Bible-based educational and ministry systems

Lead congregations confidently amid ongoing technological change

The program maintains the historic objectives of the Master of Divinity while addressing contemporary realities faced by today‚Äôs ministers.

Program Orientation
The Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry is intentionally:

Scripture-centered ‚Äì affirming the authority of the biblical text

Theologically grounded ‚Äì rooted in orthodox Christian doctrine

Pastorally oriented ‚Äì focused on the care of people and communities

Technologically discerning ‚Äì emphasizing correct and ethical use of digital tools

Graduates are equipped not merely to adopt technology, but to use it wisely, responsibly, and in service to the Church‚Äôs enduring mission.



Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry
Preparing Shepherds for Scripture, Systems, and Souls
The One-Sentence Value Proposition
This MDiv forms pastors who can faithfully preach the Word, steward the Bible in digital systems, and lead ministry in a technology-shaped world‚Äîwithout surrendering doctrine to platforms or AI.

The Problem This Degree Solves
The Church has entered the digital age without trained guardians of its infrastructure.

Today:

Pastors depend on Bible apps they cannot audit

AI summarizes Scripture without accountability

Theology is shaped by search algorithms

Digital outreach expands faster than doctrinal oversight

Scripture is increasingly mediated, normalized, and abstracted

The result is not heresy by rebellion‚Äîbut error by convenience.

This degree exists to stop that trajectory.

Why a Traditional MDiv Is No Longer Enough
A standard MDiv prepares ministers to:

Interpret Scripture

Preach and teach

Shepherd people

Lead congregations

But it does not prepare them to:

Evaluate AI-generated biblical content

Preserve Scripture digitally without corruption

Design or supervise Bible-based systems

Protect doctrine in digital delivery environments

Discern how technology shapes belief formation

This program does.

What Makes This MDiv Unique
This is not a tech degree with Bible added.
This is a divinity degree expanded to meet the realities of the digital age.

Two Integrated Pillars
1. Biblical Informatics (Foundation)
Scripture as structured, authoritative knowledge

Canon-aware data modeling

Rule-based biblical systems

AI as assistive tool, never interpreter

Digital preservation and offline-first Scripture access

Doctrinal safeguards embedded in technology

2. Digital Ministry (Application)
Online evangelism and discipleship

Digital church ecclesiology

Pastoral care in virtual contexts

Media, worship, and teaching technologies

Ethical digital leadership

üìå Informatics protects the Word
üìå Digital Ministry proclaims the Word
Together, they ensure faithful transmission and faithful proclamation.

The Graduate This Program Produces
A graduate of this MDiv is:

A pastor who understands technology

A technologist accountable to theology

A digital missionary with doctrinal discipline

A builder and evaluator of Bible-based systems

A guardian of Scripture in digital form

This is not a content creator.
This is a digital-era divinity leader.

What Students Learn to Do (Concrete Outcomes)
Graduates can:

Design and oversee Bible apps and teaching systems

Evaluate AI and digital tools for theological integrity

Build rule-based biblical assistants anchored in Scripture

Preserve and distribute Scripture offline and cross-platform

Teach the Bible using structured, mastery-based systems

Lead churches responsibly in digital environments

These are skills churches already need but cannot currently train for.

Why Churches, Schools, and Ministries Will Want This Graduate
Churches are asking:

‚ÄúCan we trust our tools?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow do we disciple people online responsibly?‚Äù

‚ÄúWho understands both theology and technology?‚Äù

Bible colleges are asking:

‚ÄúHow do we modernize without compromising?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow do we teach Scripture in a digital-native generation?‚Äù

This MDiv supplies the answer.

Long-Term Impact (Why This Degree Has Staying Power)
Trends change. Platforms fail. Tools disappear.

But this degree is:

Platform-agnostic

Technology-critical, not technology-dependent

Scripture-centered

Future-proof

It prepares leaders to adapt without surrender, innovate without distortion, and preserve truth beyond current technologies.

Why This Degree Is Timely‚ÄîNot Experimental
Every major theological shift followed a technological shift:

Writing ‚Üí Canon formation

Printing ‚Üí Reformation

Broadcasting ‚Üí Mass evangelism

Digital systems ‚Üí This moment

Biblical Informatics is simply the Church catching up responsibly.

Why the Name Works
‚ÄúMaster of Divinity‚Äù
‚Äì Signals theological seriousness and ministerial formation

‚ÄúBiblical Informatics‚Äù
‚Äì Declares Scripture as structured, safeguarded knowledge

‚ÄúDigital Ministry‚Äù
‚Äì Commits to mission, discipleship, and pastoral presence

Together, the name says:

We will not abandon the Bible to machines, nor abandon people to systems.

Bottom Line
This MDiv does not ask:

‚ÄúHow can we use technology in ministry?‚Äù

It asks:

‚ÄúHow do we ensure technology never replaces the authority of Scripture in ministry?‚Äù

That question defines leadership in this generation.


This is not a trendy degree.
It is a necessary one.


Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry
Forming Wise Stewards of Scripture and Technology
The Central Idea
Technology, like fire or a knife, is neither good nor evil by nature.
Its value depends on who wields it, how it is shaped, and for what purpose.

This Master of Divinity exists to ensure that those who handle Scripture in digital form do so wisely, faithfully, and skillfully, for the good of the Church and the glory of God.

Why This Degree Exists
The Church has always adopted tools:

Writing preserved revelation

Printing multiplied access

Radio and television extended proclamation

Digital systems now shape how Scripture is read, searched, taught, and remembered

Each tool required training and discernment.

This degree recognizes that digital technology is now part of the minister‚Äôs toolbox, and it must be handled with the same care as preaching, interpretation, and pastoral authority.

A Rightly Ordered View of Technology
This program does not treat technology as:

A threat to faith

A replacement for pastors

An authority over Scripture

Instead, it treats technology as:

A servant, not a master

A means, not a message

A tool, not a teacher

Just as fire warms a home or destroys it, and a knife prepares food or causes harm, digital tools must be shaped and governed by biblical wisdom.

The Integrated Vision of the Degree
Biblical Informatics ‚Äî Forming the Tool Properly
Biblical Informatics focuses on how Scripture is structured, preserved, and handled within digital systems so that the Word remains clear, faithful, and accessible.

Students learn to:

Treat Scripture as authoritative, structured knowledge

Design and evaluate Bible-based digital tools responsibly

Use AI and automation as assistive aids, not interpreters

Preserve Scripture for long-term digital use

Maintain doctrinal clarity within technological systems

This is about craftsmanship‚Äîmaking sure the tool itself is sound.

Digital Ministry ‚Äî Using the Tool Wisely
Digital Ministry focuses on how those tools are used in real ministry contexts‚Äîfor evangelism, discipleship, worship, and pastoral care.

Students learn to:

Lead online and hybrid congregations

Communicate the gospel effectively in digital spaces

Provide pastoral care in mediated environments

Disciple believers using digital platforms

Practice ethical and relational leadership online

This is about stewardship‚Äîusing the tool for its intended purpose.

The Graduate This Program Forms
A graduate of this MDiv is:

A pastor who understands digital tools

A teacher who knows how Scripture is mediated

A leader who uses technology thoughtfully

A steward who respects both theology and technique

A minister who builds and uses tools responsibly

Not a technocrat.
Not a skeptic.
But a wise craftsman in ministry.

What Makes This Degree Different (In a Positive Way)
This program does not resist innovation‚Äîit guides it.

It does not fear AI‚Äîit frames its proper role.

It does not abandon tradition‚Äîit extends it faithfully.

The emphasis is not on novelty, but on proper use, discernment, and long-term faithfulness.

Practical Outcomes (What Graduates Can Do)
Graduates are prepared to:

Select and supervise digital ministry tools wisely

Participate in the creation of Bible software and curricula

Use AI responsibly for research and teaching support

Preserve Scripture in accessible digital formats

Lead churches confidently in digital and physical spaces

These are increasingly normal expectations for ministry leaders today.

Why Churches and Institutions Will Welcome This Degree
Churches are not asking for more technology.
They are asking for leaders who understand how to use it well.

This MDiv provides:

Confidence instead of confusion

Discernment instead of fear

Skill instead of dependence

Faithfulness instead of novelty

Why the Name Fits the Vision
Master of Divinity
‚Äì Grounded in theology, Scripture, and pastoral formation

Biblical Informatics
‚Äì Ensuring the Word is handled carefully within digital systems

Digital Ministry
‚Äì Applying those tools faithfully in service to people

Together, the name communicates wisdom, balance, and stewardship.

Final Word
This degree does not ask ministers to choose between:

Faith and technology

Tradition and innovation

Scripture and systems

It teaches them how to hold all three rightly.

The Master of Divinity in Biblical Informatics and Digital Ministry prepares leaders who know not only what to teach, but how the tools they use shape understanding‚Äîand how to use those tools well.
